title: New Champ Select would have made Solo Queue so much better.
body:
I'm honestly perplexed why Riot chose to scrap Solo Queue, Team Ranked, Dominion, and Team Builder just for Dynamic Queue...

I would have been SO HAPPY if Riot implemented the new Champion Select for Solo Queue, because it would have greatly improved Solo Queue's quality.  All of the issues that Yolo Queue had came from its old champ select.  We went by pick order, and there would be arguments about which role and champ people wanted, and games could suck just from the old champ select alone. 

But the new Champ Select would have solved these issues and I believe everyone would have been happy with that.

Doing that while keeping Team Builder, Ranked 5's, Dominion, and improving 3v3 Twisted Treeline sounds so much healthier to than removing all those options for an inherently flawed system that many players have a problem with...shit, we could have still added hextech crafting as well.

This makes me sad, Riot.



We want Solo Queue (with the new Champ Select).

New champ select REQUIRES Dynamic queue to work. Quite a number of premades include one player who either mains support or 'bites the bullet' and learns the role so that they and their friends can have a faster queue time; without these 'premade supports', queue times would be even longer than previous solo queue- entirely dependent on the bottleneck, which is always support players. Every so often there'd be a spike of 'new support players'- AKA players who queued support for the instant queue- and they'd be terrible at the role because they only picked it secondary to actually get in a game.

Like it or not, new champ select relies on the queueing decisions that premades instigate. So, since I know you're almost certainly a hyper-toxic top, mid, or ADC main that wants the game to be 100% all about your SOLO skill- pick one. Old solo queue, old champ select? Or Dynamic queue, with new champ select? The one other option is double-triple your current queue time and every other support you have being utterly worthless.

You, good sir, don't understand how matchmaking systems work.

Basically a matchmaking system is trying to get 10 players into a game so they can play.  If there are no restrictions it can do this instantly because there's always enough Bronze players to fill out a group of 10 for that 1 Diamond player in queue.

However, just getting thrown in with anyone sucks so you want to add restrictions to the matchmaking formula.  Every restriction comes at a cost of longer queue times, however.  Why?

Look at it like this: If we have no restrictions we can get instant queues because there's always at least 10 people wanting to play the game.  Now we add a restriction that all 10 players must be within 1 rank of each other.  Now queue time takes longer because there may not be that many players close to you queueing up right now.  Wait a bit and they may show up.

So now we add another consideration.  Everybody gets to pick their roll.  Now you can't just grab any 10 people from the same skill level, you need the right 10 people.  No supports?  Well looks like you're waiting until two of them who are your same skill level show up.

But you say, premades bring in more supports?  They might, who knows, but what they definitely do is add another thing the system is trying to match.  You've got a three man in queue and seven solos so nobody gets a game until another three man of the same skill level and seven more solos come in and all those new players better be exactly the one's needed to fill out the rolls that are lacking...

"But," you say, "if matchmaking worked like that it would take forever to get in a game!"  True, I simplified a bit.  The longer you're in queue the greater the variance the queue will accept in each category.  Been waiting for two minutes?  Well now players can be two ranked apart.  Been waiting for five minutes?  Now your five man can fight five solo players.  These matches won't be as fair but it's better then waiting for a hour to play a 40 minute game.

Premades are particularly bad for queue times and match quality because they introduce elements that are much harder for the matchmaking algorithm to work with.  Firstly you cannot ever put two three man premades on the same team.  It's obvious but it means there is no amount of time and sloppy matchmaking that can build a team from certain combinations of players in queue.  Second, it's much harder to properly gage the skill/ranking of a player in a group then it is a lone player.  Some premades are just a bunch of random people who play together but don't use VoIP or any other advantage.  Their no better then a group of solos.  Other groups are coordinated and ruthless with persuasion rotations and players filling in for each others weaknesses.  These groups perform much much better then five randoms.  If the matchmaking formula assumes premades will be like the former then the later get to stomp every game while assuming the later advantage means the former gets their face caved in every match.  So most likely you assume some level of advantage in the middle and both effects happen to a lesser degree.  Yah, such balanced games!

Even if premades provided enough supports that they completely balanced out the other roles (they don't) the system would still need to make teams of 1 of each roll and account for premades which will take longer then just accounting for 1 of each roll.

Premades have a pretty negligible impact on queue timers, at least up to Plat. Just make this test: try any combination of positions and number of premades, as long as you have someone with "Support" picked in the middle, queue timers are virtually instant. The lack of Support is the only noticeable bottleneck in the system.

In theory, yes, premades make the match-making harder. But in practice, the player base is large enough that it has virtually no impact.

Firstly, lets be clear.  It's not the number of people that would make premades have a negligable impact on queue times, it's the percentage of players in premades.  You may be right that the percentage of premades are low enough that they have little impact below Platinum but then there aren't enough of them to impact the roll selection as suggested by Arakk01.

Never said I agreed with Arakk. What he said is possible but very far fetched, and we have no evidence it's actually the case.

And you're not entirely correct about premade proportions. Even a player-base with 80% of players in a 2-5 premade groups could easily be sustainable if it was large enough to compensate the problems of the type: "we have a Trio and a Duo, but their desired lanes doesn't match". And even this kind of problem is not really serious, since you have to cover 3 lanes with a Duo, 4 lanes with a Trio. That means any random Trio can be matched with any random Duo with a 40% chance probability (assuming equal distribution of lanes).

But beyond the technical details, the message I want to make clear is this: People asking for DynQ removal because of the queue timers are wrong. If we keep the New Champ Select (and everyone wants to keep it, that the only thing everyone agrees on), even in SoloQ, the timers would be sensibly the same, because the main factor driving the timers up is the lack of Support, not the complexity of matching premade groups.

There are a few debatable reasons to bring SoloQ back, but this one is not debatable at all, it's just wrong.

For your 80% scenario to work you need just the right balance of duo and trio groups or you just wind up with duos being the new support.  

But as to your main point... You're right.  DQ is probably having a negligible impact on queue times right now*.  Supports are THE bottleneck and anything that doesn't adjust that problem isn't going to do much to queue times.

 * Any increase in queue time caused by the bigger groups is only felt by the bigger groups, not by solo's at all.

My only issue with dynamic que is the ability to create artificial synergy that wouldn't exist at all in soloque. Playing against a jg/lane dynamic/duo is the most tilting thing to play against and with, because you know that that lane's the only one that's gonna get any jungle attention, and it's gonna get all the jungle attention.
Well then you should win if the jungler is paying no attention to 2 lanes because those 2 can get jungle pressure and proceed to snowball

On one hand, the entire NCS and DQ thing were intended to help out high elo match quality, master+ can't ensure they get the role because the system just dump 10 people to start a game, much like the rest of ranked population do. So they have to come up with something else to couple up with the NCS, and this is what most people ignore, it's that you can't just give people the power to strictly get what they want to play, that can and do happen in lower elo where there are just so many people whatsoever, but in high elo it will put queue time to a insane amount. So Riot decided to release DQ, so that premade had/have larger size, and that allows lower rated players (like a diamond 2 trio) to be considered as high elo players (like 3 individual masters). However, the matchmake system right now just does not work out well enough to balance the "quality of a premade" and "individual skill assessment".

So I say NCS/DQ is theoretically good for high elo however it needs massive tweaks, but for lower elo NCS alone is pretty good, DQ does make games pretty unfair.

or

> I'm honestly perplexed why Riot chose to scrap Solo Queue, Team Ranked, Dominion, and Team Builder just for Dynamic Queue...

Well, you better be perplexed. That's not why they scrapped all of that.

* Team Ranked was scrapped because they couldn't manage to get the match-making right because of wildly different goals among the player base. They hope it will be better with the new Scheduled Team Ranked by bringing more people playing at the same time and by narrowing the player base to people with similar objectives.
* Dominion was scrapped because the player-base was too small.
* Team-builder was scrapped because the queue timers were horrible, and because the New Champ Select in the Normal Draft queue solve most of the original issues that Team-builder intended to solve. (Not perfectly, but still, most of them, and with Queue Timers 2 to 3 times lower, at least.)
* That leaves only Solo Queue which was indeed scrapped in favor of Dynamic Queue. To switch the skills being tested in the ladder and put more emphasize on team-work compared to solo carrying, and to please people who wanted to play (competitively) with their friends.
